VALUER Type: VALUERSDescription: Housing HRA

description: Erection of part single storey and part two storey extension to rear in conjunction with two storey side extension to form a new self-contained two bedroom residential dwelling house, with associated parking, vehicular crossover and cycle store
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason:  As required  by Section 91 of  the Town  and Country Planning  Act  1990,  as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The development  hereby approved shall be carried out in accordance with the materials specified on the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.	Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction logistic plan has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Means of enclosure of the site.(h) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(i) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.Reason:  These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset, and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

No development shall take place until a detailed acoustic report on the existing noise climate at the development site has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.The report shall include a scheme of noise insulation measures for the new dwelling hereby approved. The noise insulation measures shall be designed to achieve noise insulation to a standard that nuisance will not be caused to the occupiers of residential accommodation by noise from the following:- The railway line to the west of the application site. The noise assessment shall be carried out by a suitably qualified acoustic consultant/engineer and shall take into account the provisions of BS 8233: 2014 Guidance on sound insulation and noise reduction for buildings. The approved scheme shall be implemented prior to the commencement of the use and be permanently maintained thereafter.Reason:  These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase, and in the interest of the future occupiers of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 of the  Council's Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

The development hereby approved shall not commence until a Sustainable Drainage Strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan of surface water drainage for the site using Suds methods has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved Sustainable Drainage Strategy prior to the first occupation of the dwelling and maintained thereafter for the lifetime of the development.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset, and to prevent the increased risk of flooding by ensuring the provision of a satisfactory means of surface water disposal is incorporated into the design and the build of the proposed development, in accordance with Policies 5.2 and 5.3 of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 of the Council's Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

Prior to the occupation of the approved development, a plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority indicating the positions, design, materials and type of all gates, boundary treatment, fences and means of enclosures to be erected.  The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved plan before the building is occupied.Reason:  To safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interest of visual amenity, in accordance with Policy DM10 of the  Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times. Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted details of refuse and recycling facilities shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times. Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory refuse and recycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The car parking accommodation shown upon the approved drawings shall be provided with a hard bound dust free surface, adequately drained before the development to which it relates is occupied and thereafter it shall be kept free from obstruction at all times for use by the occupier of the development and shall not thereafter be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of the development and visitors to it. Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking accommodation and to avoid the congestion of surrounding roads by parked vehicles in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, the first floor window fitted in the side (south) elevation shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers, in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

Prior to the occupation of the development, evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4. Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide. Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day.Reason: In the interests of Sustainability and Energy Conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 and 5.3 of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a residential dwelling.Proposal Single storey rear extensionConsultation One objection received and summarised below - Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/SunlightOfficer comment: The matters raised in the objection, character and appearance and neighbour amenity, are addressed in the officers assessment.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  Whilst it is acknowledge that the proposed development may result in an increase in shadowing to the rear of the adjacent property 2 Welbeck Close due to the height and depth of the proposed extension it is considered that, on balance, the proposed development would not have any significant adverse impact on the overall amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. It is noted that the affected windows are north facing and that there is a degree of shadowing from the existing built form of the dwellings. Overall, it is considered that the neighbouring occupiers would still have a principle unobstructed outlook down their rear garden and an adequate provision of daylight/sunlight to the property over the course of the whole day.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling. The site is located within Grove Lane Local Area of Special Character9 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;- The impact of the development and flood risk and drainage; - The impact of the development and non-designated heritage assets; and, - Fire Safety Assessment.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey rear extension would have a modest depth and height, and while it would have a slightly unusual roof form, on balance officers consider that the proposed extension would appear a modest and appropriate addition to the host property that would not detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the modest scale of the proposed development, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Flood Risk AssessmentThe application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. Officer Comment: The submitted flood risk form states that floor levels within the proposed development will be set no lower than existing levels and flood proofing of the proposed development has been incorporated where appropriate which is considered acceptable in this case and in compliance with policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).HeritageParagraph 203 of the NPPF 2021 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining anyapplication. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designatedheritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of anyharm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer Comment: As noted above the proposal would adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD and would be in keeping with host property and would not detract from the character and appearance of surrounding area, as such officers conclude that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character, but rather preserve it. Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe application site is an existing sports ground. The site is located in the designated Green BeltProposal Planning permission is sought for the demolition of existing scout hut, maintenance shed, bungalow and clubhouse and replacement with new sports pavilion building, facilities maintenance building, car parking for 61 cars and 6 mini busses and associated hard and soft landscaping with access via Chessington World of Adventures. The proposal is a revision/amendment of planning permission 17/10342/FUL which permitted with conditions (Erection of two new single storey buildings to replace the existing buildings on the site, replacement of the existing 3G sports pitch with a hockey pitch, erection of a new maintenance building and covered maintenance vehicle storage area. Proposed new parking area for 61 cars and 6 mini-buses and new vehicular access road.)It is stated that the application is necessary as the revised proposal includes a series of minor revisions to the building design, an alteration to the car park an alternative location for the maintenance building and deleting the replacement of the existing3G sports pitch with a hockey pitch from the proposal. ConsultationNo response received to the neighbour notification. LLFA Officer - No objection Tree and Landscape officer: No objection Ecology and biodiversity officer: no objection Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer: no objection Sport England no ObjectionAssessmentThe application relates to an existing sports ground in the designated Green Belt. The development proposal is for the purposes of replacing, adding to and improving the existing sports facilities on site. It is considered that the development would be an appropriate form of development in the Green Belt as outlined in Paragrapgh of the NPPF. As such it is considered that the proposed dvelopment is in principle acceptable. It is considered that the built form of the proposed development would be of an appropriate mass, scale and design in regards to the sites size and surroundings and would be subordinate to its surroundings and be of an architectural style sympathetic to its surroundings. It is considered that the proposal would not harm the openness of the Green Belt and whilst visible would not be visually intrusive or detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area. The layout of the development proposal is considered to be of a practical nature and would have an appropriate mix of hard and soft landscaping. It is considered that the proposal would not have an adverse impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. The application has been reviewed by the LPA's neighbourhood traffic engineer and no objection is raised to the level of parking, servicing or highway safety subject to appropriate conditions. The LLFA officer has reviewed the scheme in regards to flood risk and drainage and raises no objection subject to appropriate conditions The LPA's tree and landscape officer has reviewed the scheme and raises no objection subject to appropriate conditions The LPA's Biodiversity officer has reviewed the scheme and raises no objection subject to appropriate consitions. The proposal would involve the use of the site by community beyond the principle user Shrewsbury House School. As such a community use agreement  is to be drawn up so as to control the use and it impacts and this is to be secured by condition.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

The site comprises a detached dwelling located within the Southborough Conservation Area. Representations:Surbiton Conservation Area Advisory Committee - no objection.Tree and Landscape Officer - additional information is required to ensure that the proposal would not result in an unacceptable adverse impact on the protected trees.5 surrounding owners/occupiers were notified of the proposals.  No letters were received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on the Southborough Conservation Area; and,- The impact of the development on the protected trees; and,- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey rear extension would be of a total height of approx. 3.7m and approx. 4.6m deep, it would join the existing single storey rear extension, which depth of approx. 3.7m would not change. It is noted that the proposal includes refurbishment and alterations to fenestration of the existing extension and existing balcony including addition of a parapet wall.It is acknowledged that the proposed single storey rear extension would not be strictly in accordance with Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD with regards to the recommended depth and height. However, considering its modest scale, the proposed design and materials and its siting, it is considered that the proposed extension would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition in relation to the host dwelling. It is noted that due to the existing boundary treatment comprising mature trees along the boundary with No. 3 Langley Avenue and the scale of the proposed development, the proposed works would not be visible from the street, therefore there would be no impact of the proposal on the existing street scene.Given the above, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Heritage AssetsSection 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                                                                                  In determining planning applications which affect heritage assets, Paragraph  192 of the NPPF 2019 requires local planning authorities to take account of: the desirability of sustaining and enhancing the significance of heritage assets and putting them to viable uses consistent with their conservation; the positive contribution that conservation of heritage assets can make to sustainable communities including their economic vitality; and the desirability of new development making a positive contribution to local character and distinctiveness.                                                                                                                     Paragraph 193 of NPPF 2019 states that when considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the assets conservation, irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts of substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.                                              Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer comment: The application site falls within the Southborough Conservation Area. The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as an area of large detached houses dating from the 1860s - 1930s surrounding Southborough House, an 1808 Grade II listed building by the architect John Nash.The application property is not listed or locally listed, but nonetheless contributes positively to the conservation area. As the proposal would not be visible from the public vantage points and due to its scale, the proposed design and materials, it is considered that the proposed single storey rear extension and the proposed alterations would be in-keeping with the host dwelling, therefore the proposed development would be appropriate for the property located within a conservation area. Having regard to the above, officers conclude that the proposal would not result in any harm to the conservation area and would preserve its significance. It is therefore not necessary to weigh the proposed development against any public benefits.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.Protected TreesOfficers note comments from the Council's Tree and Landscape Officer regarding outstanding information required to ensure that the proposal would not result in an unacceptable adverse impact upon the longevity, health and appearance of the protected trees that are immediately adjacent on the boundary with No 3 Langley Avenue.This information will be secured via a relevant condition.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

When submitting a new application the applicant is advised to provide a detailed Arboricultural Method Statement and Tree Protection Plan to demonstrate how the proposal would affect the protected trees.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey semi-detached dwellinghouse located on Cleaveland Road. The site is situated within the Cleaveland Road/The Mall Local Area of Special Character. Consultations13 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on heritage assets.The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application partly proposes the construction of a two storey rear extension which would extend  rear wall of the dwellinghouse. This extension would have a gable ended roof and would measure approximately 5.8 metres at its maximum height. Officers consider that the proposed two storey rear extension would appear proportionate and subordinate to the original dwellinghouse and would be appropriate in scale and design. Officers also note that an extension of this proportion and design would not be uncharacteristic to a property along Cleaveland Road.  The application also proposes the construction of a single storey rear extension which would measure approximately 6.4 metres in depth from the rear wall of the dwellinghouse. The extension would have a parapet wall and would measure approximately 3.3 metres at its maximum height. Whilst the proposed development would exceed the recommended depth as outlined by the Residential Design SPD, officers consider that this element of the proposal would appear proportionate and subordinate to the dwellinghouse. There would be no adverse impact on the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse and area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, or loss of light. However the application proposes the installation of one window on the side elevation facing the adjoining property at No. 7 Cleaveland Road. In the interests of the privacy of this neighbouring property, officers consider it appropriate to attach a condition to the recommendation in the event of an approval to ensure that this window is obscure glazed and fixed shut 1.7 metres above floor level.   Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements. Paragraph 203 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Officers Comments: The site is located within a Cleaveland Road/The Mall Local Area of Special Character (LASC), which is considered a non-designated heritage asset. As also stated above, Officers consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the host property and the character and appearance of the wider area. It follows, that Officers consider that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the significance of the Cleaveland Road/The Mall LASC.London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The application site is a two storey terrace building with a ground floor commercial unit and upper floor flats. The building forms part of a small parade of shops designated as Kingston Hill and Park Road Local Centre but the site is otherwise in a predominantly residential area. The existing building is not statutorily or locally listed and the site is not within a Conservation Area. The Park Road Conservation Area lies approximately 35m to the south east and the Princess Road; Arthur Road and Borough Road Local Area of Special Character lies on the opposite side of Park Road. The site is within an Article 4 Area.The site is within a CPZ (Zone B - Canbury Main Area)16 neighbouring properties have been notified with no responses received.Planning HistoryAny relevant planning history for the site has been taken into account in considering this application and recent planning history is available to view on the Council's website.The key areas of assessment are:Design Impact on neighbour amenityLoss of parkingDesign Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Policy Guidance 34 of the Residential Design SPD:o	Two storey extensions may be acceptable where the dwelling sits on a spacious plot with substantial distances between boundaries and adjacent dwelling. o	Extensions proposed on the boundary of a semi-detached property are generally unacceptable and will normally be resisted. o	Adequate separation distances between neighbouring properties should be maintained (as discussed above).o	Adequate daylighting and sunlighting of neighbouring properties should be maintained using the 45 and 25 degree principles discussed above. o	On narrow width properties - particularly terraced properties, two storey rear extensions are unlikely to be appropriate as they often result in an unreasonable loss of daylight, sunlight and outlook for adjoining properties. o	The roof should relate well to the host property and its existing roof and should not be higher than the ridge of the existing roof. o	The roof should never encroach on the sill of windows of the 2nd floor. o	Flat roofs should generally be avoided unless a flat roof is a feature of the existing building, and the use of a flat roof for a roof terrace or balcony at two-storey height will generally not be acceptable as it may give rise to overlooking of neighbouring properties.Officers Comment: A 2.5 storey rear extension is proposed. Ground levels vary across the site and so the rear extension is set slightly lower than the main building, extending over 3 floors. The rear extension extends 6.3m from the main building to the extent of the ground floor extension and an additional 1.5m beyond the existing first floor extension (which has a pitched roof). Whilst the proposal will disrupt the balance and rhythm with the adjacent 57 Park Road (which has a matching ground/first floor extension), the proposed extension is discretely located to the rear and it is accepted that there are various other similar scaled rear extensions along this terrace and in the wider area.The extension has a mansard roof design which differs from the main dwelling but it is accepted that there are a variety of room forms in the surrounding area and the mansard design is considered compatible with the host building. The eaves of the extension sit below those of the main building and the ridge also sits below the existing ridge and rear dormer to the property.Due to its siting, the proposal will not impact on the nearby Park Road Conservation Area or Princess Road; Arthur Road and Borough Road Local Area of Special Character.Overall, the proposed extension is considered acceptable by reason of its design, siting, form, scale and materials and would not result in a detrimental impact on the host property or character and appearance of the area. As such, the proposal is in accordance with Policy D3 of the London Plan (2021) and Policies CS8 and DM 10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and Residential Design Guide SPD (2013).Neighbour AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer's comment: The most affected properties are No. 61 and 57 Park Road and No. 26 Glenville Road. With regard to No. 57 Park Road, the proposed extension extends only approximately 1.5m beyond the existing first floor rear dormer to this property. Given the limited extent beyond this dormer, this is not considered to be overbearing or to result in an undue loss of daylight or sunlight to this neighbour. There are no flank windows facing this neighbour and so there will be no loss of privacy also.With regard to No. 61 Park Road, there is a small first floor window directly opposite the proposed extension but planning records for the neighbouring site indicate this to be a bathroom (non-habitable). There is a rear facing first floor window also serving a bedroom. Outlook will be affected from this window but the rear extension is set lower than this window with only the uppermost part of the extension and the mansard (which tapers away from the window) likely to be visible. On this basis, and given the existing constrained nature of the area, this is not considered to give rise to an overbearing impact for this neighbour. New rear facing windows will overlook this property but it does not appear to have any meaningful amenity space to the rear and any increased overlooking would not be significantly beyond the established level of overlooking in the area. A window is proposed on the side of the extension which would look directly towards the rear dormer of this neighbour but this serves a bathroom and can be conditioned as obscure glazed.  A 45 degree test has been undertaken which concludes that the extension will not result in an undue loss of daylight or sunlight to this window. With regard to No. 26 Glenville Road, the proposed extension will directly faces the flank wall to this property which does not have any openings. It will therefore not be overbearing or result in any undue levels of overlooking to tis neighbour or its rear garden (which is located further to the south). For these reasons, the proposed development is not considered to unduly affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy, subject to conditions. The proposal is in accordance with Policy DM 10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and Residential Design Guide SPD (2013).It is noted that the proposed development is in the vicinity of a number of businesses within the Kingston Hill and Park Road Local Centre. The Environmental Health Officer has reviewed the application and raises no objection. It is therefore considered that the proposals would not give rise to any unreasonable restrictions on neighbouring businesses as a result of the proposed intensified residential use.

We are still waiting for the plan, dated 2nd May to be re-titled on the plan itself. It is currently titled under Drawing Title  "Sections", but shows the Site Location Plan, Existing and Proposed drawings etc. We cannot validate until all plans have the correct Drawing Titles.

Please provide a copy of proposed block plan drawn at an identified standard metric scale (such as 1:200 or 1:500) showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The block plan must show the direction of North and should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.

Please provide a Block Plan drawn at an identified standard metric scale (such as 1:200 or 1:500) showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The Block Plan must show the direction of North and should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.

Please provide Existing Floor Plans stating a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example) preferably with a scale bar, and showing the outline of the entire floor plan, not just part and all key dimensions for the proposed works. The plans must also show the direction of North.

Please provide Existing Front, Rear and Side Elevations at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example) preferably with a scale bar, showing all elevations not just part and indicating all key dimensions for the proposed work.

Please provide Existing Roof Plans at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example) preferably with a scale bar, showing the outline of the entire property not just part and showing dimensions of proposed work. The plans must show the direction of North.

The fee required for your planning application is 206.  Payment can be made via either our Contact Centre on 0208 547 5002, by cheque made payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames or online via the Kingston council website.

Please provide existing floor plans at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing the outline of entire floor plan, not just part and all key dimensions for the proposed works. The plans must also show the direction of North. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is encouraged.

Please provide the Other Side existing and proposed Elevation at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing all elevations not just part and indicating all key dimensions for the proposed work.

Please clarify what should be shown at the first floor above the former garage. The elevations show the garage is single storey, however the proposed floor plans show rooms at the first floor. It will help if you provide Existing and Proposed Roof Plans for clarification.
